text: today I'm really excited to talk about
custards because they are one of my
favorite things in front of me today I
have a soft rich custard like a creme
brulee here and then I have something
that's a little bit more firm and glossy
like this flan and the main difference
between the two comes down to two
ingredients the eggs or egg yolks so in
the case of a creme brulee you have a
richer softer silkier texture and the
egg portion or ratio of that mix is egg
yolk that differs from flan and creme
caramel something that can live outside
of its custard cup you would use whole
eggs or sometimes there's even an
addition of egg whites as well and that
gives the firmness that you need to
unmold a swan or a creme caramel now the
other difference is the dairy that goes
into them creme brulee is typically made
with a heavy cream so something that has
a higher fat content that gives it a
richer texture and usually with flan or
creme caramels you would use whole milk
now just to show you the texture of what
I'm talking about
this creme brulee that we've made here
you can see the custard is very very
soft and it would never be able to live
outside of this ramekin in comparison
this flan is living outside of its
ramekin and you can see that the texture
is quite firm it's still silky and
delicious but the thickness and the
gelling potential really comes from the
whole egg and in particular the egg
whites which add structure and strength
to this custard I'm going to be making a
flan and how do we start that well we
start that with the caramel which goes
into the bottom of the ramekin add one
cup of granulated sugar into the bottom
of a small pot here and to that I'm
going to add a quarter of a cup of water
now whenever I'm making caramels I
prefer to use the wet caramel method
which is what I'm demonstrating here
today and that is in adding a good
amount of water what that does is it
helps to dissolve the sugar and help the
sugar to caramelize even
when you're making a caramel have a
pastry brush and some water and as this
caramel is bubbling up small little
crystals of sugar might appear on the
side of the pan you can use the brush to
brush any of those crystals down and
what works just as well is a lid because
what happens here is as the caramel
cooks it creates steam the steam
collects on the top of the lid and then
it trickles down the sides of the pan
washing those crystals back down into
the sugar syrup you want a really dark
amber color and that's going to take
anywhere from four to five to even six
minutes so it's been about four minutes
and our caramel is just starting to turn
a very very light amber color if your
sugar syrup does crystallize we made a
video about this just go to our video
what to do if your caramel crystallizes
and you can easily fix it now whenever
you're making caramel always remember
the caramel will seem darker than it is
in this pan as opposed to when it will
be in the bottom of your ramekin because
the pot is so dark so don't fear this go
a little bit darker than you might be
comfortable with because you really want
that dark developed flavor and if your
caramel is too blonde it's not going to
have the flavor you need this looks good
I'm going to turn the heat off and I
have six six ounce ramekins in front of
me and I'm going to evenly distribute
the caramel into the bottom of each
ramekin you want to do this quickly
because your caramel is still cooking
you want to let it cool slightly and
what you can do is you can pick the rim
and cannot be very careful here guys and
you want to start swirling it around the
cup slightly so it comes up maybe an
inch along the side and then you want to
let these ramekins cool while you make
the custard base we're making a flan so
we're using five whole eggs to this I'm
going to add one cup of regular
granulated sugar a quarter teaspoon of
coarse salt with these three ingredients
together and while this is kind of just
hanging out here I'm going to add the
dairy portion to the pan so I have two
and a quarter cups of whole milk again
we're making the flan so we're using
whole eggs and we're also using lower
fat dairy which is the whole milk and
I'm also going to add 3/4 of a cup of
coconut-cream bring this up to a simmer
and then going to temper this hot milk
mixture into our eggs so that they do
not curdle it's just about at a simmer
here and now I'm going to temper it into
the eggs now tempering again it's that
process of bringing the temperatures of
the two ingredients together so if you
added this hot milk in in one dump it
would curdle your eggs so you want to do
it gradually so I'll do maybe a quarter
of a cup whisking constantly I'll add a
little bit more the coconut milk it
actually does really add a wonderful
flavor it really smells great too and
the last bit and now for a little bit of
flavor I'm going to add in a teaspoon of
vanilla extract look a hefty teaspoon of
vanilla extract if you wanted to flavor
this with something else you could
certainly do that a little bit of spice
is really nice in a flan you could also
do a coffee extracts would be really
wonderful here now just for added
security I'm going to strain this
mixture just in case there are any
little Pregnant's of egg white or
something that hasn't been properly
dissolved strain this mixture through a
fine mesh sieve into a batter bowl or
something with a spout that easily pours
so now evenly divide your custard
between these ramekins make sure your
oven is preheated to 325 degrees you
want the rack to be in the middle of the
oven and these custards will cook
anywhere between 40 to 60 minutes until
they jiggle slightly in the center
another way to ensure that these
custards are cooking evenly is to cook
them in a water bath so bring this pan
to your oven have a tea kettle of hot
water ready you're going to pour into
the pan and you want the water to come
up halfway up the sides of the custard
cup so into the oven the custards have
been in the oven for about 45 minutes
and you want a slight jiggle in the
center of the custards you can see that
it's slightly jiggling you don't want to
cook them beyond that otherwise your
custard can run the risk of over baking
and it will be
a little too firm my weird little tip
here is take some tongs and wrap them
with small towels and secure them with
rubber bands here and it will help you
remove these hot ramekins from the water
it kind of grips the ramekin and you
don't risk the ramekins slipping out
from your tongs or burning yourself so
these will cool down to room temperature
that will take about maybe 40 minutes to
an hour and then right into the
refrigerator until they're completely
cool and then we'll be ready to unmold
them our custards have been in the
refrigerator takes about six hours but
they can go longer than that
take a small paring knife something that
has a thin blade a flexible blade is
really helpful and you want to glide the
blade of the knife around the perimeter
of the flan take your plate
invert it right over the top and then
you're going to give this a good flip
and hopefully your flan will come right
out if it gives you a little bit of
trouble what might be the issue here is
just suction so take the blade of the
knife and gently coax the flan out and
if you release the suction you should
have a beautiful flan with a nice fluid
caramel custard they're relatively easy
to make at home it just depends on what
type of coasters you're going to be
making I hope that I've taught you guys
